awd_titl_txt: Viral Amplification of Recombinant RNA In Transgenic Plants
awd_abstract_narration: 9402103  Abstract  Turpen  The interaction of plants and their viruses present unique  opportunities for the production of complex molecules. Tobacco  Mosaic Virus (TMV) is the type member of the tobamovirus group and  is one of the best understood viruses in all aspects of their  biology. Using existing technology for the construction of  recombinant RNA viruses and transgenic hosts, we propose to use  viral RNA amplification for the synthesis of defined products in  plants. In Phase II, we will determine the necessary and optimal  configuration of episomal sequences to achieve the goal of  controlled and biologically contained, high level gene expression  in whole plants.  %%%  The most highly expressed genes in plants are found encoded in  plant RNA viral genomes. In order to develop a plant virus as a  gene vector, we will design constructs which retain the ability to  generate infectious recombinants and, as such, will no longer be  limited in their use as gene vectors. Thus, the production of  complex molecules on a commercial basis will be greatly optimized.  ***
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships
